support.p: Historic Environment Record ID: Monument number: 428762
support.desc: At the top of the stone, there is a cross within a circle on each face.

supportDesc.condition: An inscribed pillar-stone that was subsequently made into a cross (Okasha 1993, 224). Macalister suggested that the Latin text, which he described as being in good condition (1945, 451), seems to have been accompanied by an echo in Ogham letters, which have been intentionally broken away (1945, 452). The evidence for an ogham inscription provided by Macalister was extremely deteriorated at the time and is therefore very doubtful: there is a flake on the left-hand edge which begins and ends with the sides of vowel notches: three disintegrated vowel notches can be traced above, the whole making the final I of MAQI. Below the I there is a Q, much again the angle is violently smashed, clearly with intention. There is just room for VITALI in Ogham letters in this fractured space. The opposite angle is also smashed, and the distribution of the fractures corresponds generally to the position and extent of Ogham scores which would express the word TORICI (not TORRICI) read upward (1945, 452). Forsyth reviewed the 3D model of the stone but there does not seem to be any traces of ogham letters extant today.

layoutDesc.layout: The Latin inscription is on the east face of the stone as it stands at present, and consists of four words written in a vertical line reading downwards (Macalister 1945, 452). According to Macalister, there were also traces of an ogham inscription on the edge of the left-hand side and the front of the shaft of the stone (Okasha 1993, 224). However, Okasha maintained that it is unlikely that the stone ever contained an ogham text (1993, 226).

handDesc.handNote: Macalister observed that the topmost word is in smaller and more cursive letters than the other three, and clearly forms a separate and later inscription, and subsequently concluded that the two inscriptions are not palaeographically compatible, and must be kept apart (1945, 452). Thomas noted that the inscription contained an angle-bar A and a horizontal I (1994, 270). The letters RI are ligatured. The letters measure 6 to 14 cm in height (1993, 224).

history.provenance: First mentioned by William Borlase in 1754 when the stone served as a gate-post for the entrance to St. Clement's Vicarage (Macalister 1945, 451). The stone was recorded in the rectory garden in 1863 and moved to its present location in 1938 (Okasha 1993, 224).
In St Clement churchyard, near the south door.

app.note: The stone is marked as an ogham stone on the Ordnance Survey Map of Britain in the Dark Ages, but there is no ogham inscription listed for this stone on the CISP database. Macalister alone suggested the possibility of an ogham inscription that complemented the Latin inscription, but there is little evidence to support that an ogham inscription existed.

div.p: Roman: Ignioc. [The stone] of Vitalius, son of Torricus

Thomas stated that Vitalis is a Roman name, one of some distinction (1994, 270). Okasha surmised that if the name VITALI is Latin, this suggests a sixth to eighth century date for the stone, a date which the use of horizontal I probably corroborates (1993, 226).
